Lady Sings the Blues is the fiercely honest, no-holds-barred autobiography of Billie Holiday, the legendary jazz, swing, and standards singing sensation. We are with her during the mesmerizing debut of ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œStrange FruitÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½; with her as she rubs shoulders with the biggest movie stars and musicians of the day (Bob Hope, Lana Turner, Clark Gable, Benny Goodman, Lester Young, Coleman Hawkins, and more); and with her through the scrapes with Jim Crow, spats with Sarah Vaughan, ignominious jailings, and tragic decline. All of this is told in HolidayÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s tart, streetwise style and hip patois that makes it read as if it were written yesterday.

The book was  re-released in late July. Expanding on the original, the publisher has added a foreword and a complete listing of Holiday's discography, both by writer David Ritz
